Talaromyces atroroseus is a filamentous ascomycete fungus that belongs to the genus Talaromyces. This species is known for its ability to produce a distinctive red pigment called monascorubrin, which gives it a characteristic deep red or pinkish-red color.

Talaromyces atroroseus is a member of the Trichocomaceae family and is commonly found in soil and plant-associated environments. It is a slow-growing fungus that forms a velvety or granular texture on culture media.

Morphologically, Talaromyces atroroseus produces septate hyphae and produces conidiophores that bear chains of smooth-walled, globose to subglobose conidia. The fungus also produces distinctive sclerotia-like structures called ascomata, which contain the sexual spores (ascospores) produced by the fungus.

Talaromyces atroroseus is of interest due to its potential applications in the production of natural pigments, as well as its ability to degrade certain types of organic compounds. Ongoing research is exploring the biosynthetic pathways and genetic regulation of the monascorubrin pigment production in this fungal species.
